name: 1. Introduction
content:
Auto-Mobile Insurance Claims Analytics


Project Overview :

Auto-Mobile Insurance Claims Analytics is a data-driven project aimed at enhancing the predictive analytics framework within the automobile insurance industry. The project focuses on analyzing, predicting, and detecting anomalies in automobile insurance claims data, helping insurance companies optimize operations, reduce fraudulent claims, and better assess risks.

The project involves processing two primary datasets: insurance claims data and insurance policies data. These datasets contain critical information about claim incidents, policy details, claim amounts, suspicious activities, and customer demographics. By leveraging this data, the goal is to develop a predictive model to classify claims, detect fraud, and improve decision-making processes for underwriters.


Key Objectives :

1. Fraud Detection

  • Objective: Develop a classification model to predict whether a claim is fraudulent (based on the suspicious_activity flag).
  • Approach: Use supervised machine learning algorithms like Random Forest, Logistic Regression, and XGBoost to classify claims based on the available data (e.g., claim amounts, incident severity, number of witnesses).
  • Metrics: Accuracy, Precision, Recall, F1-score, ROC-AUC will be used to evaluate the modelâ€™s performance.

2. Risk Assessment

  • Objective: Estimate the likelihood of a claim leading to high payouts.
  • Approach: Analyze historical claim data to predict claim severity and total claim amounts. Regression techniques will be applied to predict claim payouts.
  • Metrics: Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), and R-squared will assess the accuracy of the predictions.

3. Customer Insights

  • Objective: Provide insights into customer behavior and policy characteristics that lead to frequent claims or fraudulent activities.
  • Approach: Perform exploratory data analysis (EDA) to uncover trends related to customer demographics (e.g., age, relationship to insured) and policy details.
  • Visualizations: Histograms, scatter plots, and correlation matrices will be used to explore relationships between variables.
